name: Abercrombie
reason: Abercrombie & Fitch has evolved from dark and moody to a much brighter, cleaner aesthetic online. The site now uses mainly black text on white, with gentle grays for depth. This subdued palette feels more mature and premium, aligning with their brand refresh. It's highly legible and lets the richer colors of the apparel (often neutrals, denim blues, etc.) provide visual interest. The lack of a strong accent color reflects a modern, minimalist luxury feel and avoids the eye strain of the old dark theme.

name: Accuweather
reason: AccuWeather’s bright orange sun icon and accents convey energy and clarity, making weather alerts stand out. Coupled with black text on white, it assures users of reliable information at a glance.

name: Acer
reason: Acer’s trademark green infuses the site with a fresh, lively energy. That green is balanced by a calm slate gray and lots of white space, so the interface remains open and user-friendly. Black text on white ensures information pops. The overall vibe is energetic yet approachable, fitting for a consumer electronics leader.

name: Adidas1
reason: Adidas keeps things crisp with lots of white and black (similar to Nike), but occasionally you’ll see a hint of the Adidas blue (for example, in the Originals logo or a link). The design feels very modern and unfussy. The blue, when used, adds a touch of personality and sports heritage without cluttering the monochrome aesthetic, maintaining a balance between energy and clarity.

name: Adidas2
reason: A vibrant Golden Dream yellow (#EDE734) punctuates Adidas's largely black-and-white design, injecting energy and highlighting calls-to-action (e.g. promotions or member sign-ups). The high contrast of black text and white background ensures information is easy to read, while the bold yellow (complemented occasionally by red for sales) reflects the brand's dynamic athletic spirit.

name: Adminkit
reason: Familiar default-BS hues guarantee proven contrast & user familiarity; easy brand adaptation via Sass vars. (

name: Adobe
reason: Neutral dark UI keeps color perception true; red accent appears sparingly to minimize distraction.

name: Adobe1
reason: Pure red spot-colour instantly signals brand; restrained greys let imagery shine. ( Adobe)

name: Adobe2
reason: Adobe's design features its iconic red prominently (e.g. logo and highlights), conveying creativity and urgency. This vibrant red is balanced by ample neutral space – white backgrounds and light gray sections – so content remains the focus. Dark charcoal text provides readability and a professional tone. The overall effect is energetic without overwhelming the user, matching Adobe's image as a creative powerhouse while remaining user-friendly.

name: Adobe3
reason: Adobe’s brand red stands out boldly against a white canvas, reflecting creativity and energy. Secondary warm hues (orange/yellow) and black text balance the palette, making content and interface elements clear.

name: Adp
reason: ADP’s website features a bold red as its primary brand color, communicating confidence and urgency (used in the logo and key buttons). This strong red is tempered by neutral tones: a lot of white space and light gray sections give breathing room, while charcoal black text and accents provide a solid, professional foundation. A touch of blue is occasionally employed for contrast (e.g. links or secondary CTAs). The effect is a bold yet trustworthy corporate feel, ideal for a global HR software leader.

name: Ae
reason: American Eagle’s site uses a cool navy blue (#003366) as a key color (a nod to denim and their logo), set against lots of white. This gives a clean, all-American look. Black text and subtle gray touches keep the interface straightforward. The navy accent appears in headers or buttons, adding personality without diminishing clarity. The scheme feels fresh and laid-back, resonating with a youth casual brand, and maintains excellent readability throughout.

name: Airbnb
reason: “Rausch red” elicits warmth; sunshine yellow highlights experiences, aiding discoverability. (brand Color Code, U.S. brand colors)

name: Alibabacloud
reason: Vibrant orange captures optimism & high energy common in SME focus. (

name: Aliexpress1
mood: Bold and high-contrast, using fiery warm tones that create a sense of urgency and excitement (typical of a deal-focused site). The mood is energetic and sale-driven, with orange-red hues against clean white.
reason: Bright orange and red define AliExpress’s interface, instantly signaling deals and discounts. These warm colors grab attention (e.g. sale banners) and create a sense of urgency. Meanwhile, liberal use of white and gray for backgrounds ensures the vivid colors don’t overwhelm. The overall effect is bold and promotional – great for visibility, though the aggressive tones can feel a bit busy during heavy sale events.

name: Aliexpress2
reason: The bright orange and red of AliExpress evoke urgency and excitement, fitting for flash deals and discounts. Set against a neutral white interface with black text, these warm tones grab attention to sales and buttons, energizing the shopping experience without compromising legibility.

name: Allegro
mood: Energetic and engaging. Allegro’s design features a strong orange theme (echoing its logo) that feels enthusiastic and friendly. Set against white and light grays, the orange gives a lively, sales-oriented mood akin to a bustling marketplace, but with a modern interface.
reason: Allegro’s orange is instantly welcoming – it conveys enthusiasm and catches the eye for calls-to-action or important info. The site smartly uses this vivid hue for key UI elements (e.g. add-to-cart buttons or promo banners), while the majority of content sits on white or subtle gray backgrounds. This ensures that product listings are easy to read and that when orange appears, it directs user focus effectively. The palette feels consistent and on-brand (orange is very much associated with Allegro in Poland), imparting a sense of reliability and familiarity to users – much like Target’s red or Amazon’s orange, Allegro’s orange has become a marker of its marketplace. If overused, orange could overwhelm, but Allegro avoids that by limiting large fields of color, so overall it’s an effective scheme.

name: Alteryx
reason: Alteryx’s design employs a bold orange as its highlight color, conveying energy and creativity in data analytics. This orange is striking against the predominantly white and light ivory backgrounds, immediately drawing attention to CTAs or important visuals. A dark blue-gray serves as a contrasting accent (for headers, footers, or data charts), adding a serious analytical tone to balance the fun of orange. The combination feels bold yet analytical – the bright orange inspires innovation while the deep blue-gray assures precision. Dark slate-colored text provides strong contrast and readability. This palette mirrors Alteryx’s mission: making advanced analytics approachable and exciting.

name: Amazon1
reason: Warm orange conveys approachability; deep navy grounds dense docs. (SchemeColor)

name: Amazon2
mood: Same Amazon style – very neutral with the signature orange accent for key elements.
reason: Amazon Canada maintains the standard Amazon color system, demonstrating the brand’s consistency. The site feels identical to Amazon US in color and layout, which reinforces user trust and ease (no learning curve).

name: Amazon3
mood: Practical and utilitarian, with neutral backgrounds and a vibrant accent. It feels trustworthy and focused on function, using color sparingly for calls-to-action.
reason: The neutral white background with black text maximizes readability, while Amazon’s bold orange draws attention to key actions (e.g. “Add to Cart”). The dark navy header grounds the layout and subtly reinforces brand identity. Overall, the scheme is high-contrast and user-friendly, letting product images shine without visual distraction.

name: Amazon4
reason: Amazon’s signature orange for call-to-action buttons and navy blue for links convey a reliable, no-nonsense shopping experience. The neutral whites and dark charcoal headers provide a clean backdrop, with the orange highlights drawing attention to deals and “Add to Cart” actions.

name: Amd
reason: Jet-black UI spotlit by punch-red highlights screams gaming power, still passes contrast. ( ColorXS)

name: Amd
reason: AMD's use of bold red and orange accents conveys energy and innovation, fitting for a high-performance tech brand. These warm tones are balanced by cool touches (a teal blue and plenty of white/black) so the site doesn't overwhelm. The combination feels cutting-edge and aggressive in a positive way, capturing AMD's competitive spirit while keeping content legible.

name: Ant
reason: Keeps signature blue while low-luminance neutrals reduce eye-strain in data-heavy apps.

name: Ant
reason: Extended monochrome blue scale lets designers emphasize hierarchy with tint alone—clean and professional.

name: Anthropologie
reason: Anthropologie introduces a gentle “pear” yellow-green accent (#E6D73E) in places, giving a whimsical, creative twist to an otherwise classic black-and-white foundation. This touch of offbeat color mirrors the brand’s eclectic, artistic vibe without sacrificing readability. The design still feels airy and upscale; the unique accent just adds personality and a focal point for certain UI elements, making the site experience more memorable.

name: Apple
reason: OLED-black turns imagery into “hero”, accent blue pops for tap targets; WCAG-AA contrast upheld. (ColorHexa)

name: Apple Music
mood: Bright and upbeat – the light theme feels open and minimal, letting album art shine. The pink/red accents (official Apple Music brand colors) add a lively, youthful energy.
reason: Apple uses a predominantly white UI to convey simplicity and focus on content. The bold pink/red accent from its logo provides brand recognition and draws attention to interactive elements. In light mode, this high contrast palette aligns with Apple’s clean, modern aesthetic while highlighting important actions.

name: Apple Music
mood: Sleek and intimate – the dark theme feels immersive and edgy. White and gray text on pure black creates a high-contrast, cinematic look , while the energetic pink/red accents retain their punch against the darkness.
reason: Dark mode uses dimmer backgrounds and brighter foregrounds to reduce eye strain at night. Apple’s choice of true black for backgrounds (especially on OLED screens) makes album artwork and pink highlights “pop,” delivering a bold, concert-like experience. The consistency of accent colors across modes ensures the brand’s playful, passionate tone remains clear.

name: Apple1
reason: Apple’s palette centers on black and white for a timeless, minimalist aesthetic. Small touches of blue (for links/buttons) provide visual cues without clutter. The high contrast black-on-white typography is extremely legible, and the sparse use of color accents draws attention to key interactive elements, reflecting Apple’s clean, premium brand image.

name: Apple2
reason: A minimalist black/gray palette with a subtle blue accent creates a modern, clean feel. High contrast between black text and white backgrounds makes content easy to read and looks elegant.

name: Apple3
reason: Stark white space lets vivid “Apple Blue” drive calls-to-action while deep graphite text anchors contrast.

name: Apple4
reason: Apple uses a nearly all-neutral palette – crisp white backgrounds, Shark gray text (#1D1D1F), and subtle gray UI elements – to let product imagery shine. A hint of Science Blue (#0066CC) on links provides a touch of color for interactivity, maintaining a clean, modern aesthetic that feels premium and uncluttered.

name: Armani
reason: Armani’s site often exudes the same understated sophistication as its clothing lines. A dark theme is common for Armani – black or charcoal backgrounds create a cinematic, gallery-like experience, allowing the luxurious product photography to stand out dramatically. White or light gray text on those dark backgrounds ensures that navigation and descriptions remain legible. The use of any accent color is minimal to nonexistent; perhaps a subtle silver-gray (#777777) might be used for borders or secondary text, reinforcing a polished feel. This monochromatic approach may seem conservative, but it conveys a sense of luxury and focus. It’s easy on the eyes in low-light settings and feels very premium. The absence of loud colors keeps the mood serene and exclusive, which is exactly the aura Giorgio Armani cultivates.

name: Asana
reason: Asana’s brand color is a distinctive coral pink-orange, which gives the site a friendly, upbeat vibe. This warm hue is used in logos and highlight graphics, immediately setting Asana apart from more conservative enterprise tools. It’s balanced by deep navy for text and some accents, adding seriousness for contrast. The site heavily uses white and a faint blush background in sections, maintaining a clean and airy layout. This mix of playful color and lots of white space reflects Asana’s ethos of making work tracking delightful yet efficient for teams.

name: Asus
reason: ASUS employs a strong blue as its primary hue, signaling reliability and tech-focus, with minimal other colors. The mostly black/gray text on white interface appears bold yet professional. The blue highlights important elements (like links or icons), giving the site a cohesive, confident feel aligned with a leading tech brand.

name: Atlassian1
reason: Atlassian’s design uses its well-known blue hues prominently, signaling trust and teamwork. A deep blue for headers and logos is complemented by a brighter blue for icons and highlights, adding energy. Generous white space and very light gray backgrounds create an uncluttered canvas, making content and navigation clear. Dark navy text ensures legibility. The use of two shades of blue suggests depth and collaboration (multiple products under one brand), and overall the palette feels coherent and user-friendly – fitting for a company known for its collaboration tools.

name: Atlassian2
reason: Deep azure plus airy neutrals reflect teamwork ethos; gradient blue keeps energy. (Atlassian Design System)

name: Audi
reason: Audi’s minimal use of color – a sharp red accent and plenty of silver, black, and white – conveys modern elegance. The design mood is high-contrast and premium, with the bright red used sparingly so it grabs attention without compromising the sleekness.

name: Avito1
mood: Playful and diverse, reflecting a marketplace of many categories. Avito’s design carries a multi-color motif (blue, red, green, purple) reminiscent of Google’s approach, giving a friendly, community vibe.
reason: Avito’s use of multiple bright colors makes the platform feel welcoming and lively, each color possibly tagging a category or simply echoing the logo’s fun spots. Despite the rainbow touch, the design isn’t overwhelming because colors are mostly in icons or small elements; the layout stays clean with black text on white for listings. The variety of hues can subconsciously signal a wide variety of goods, enhancing the marketplace feel. One downside is a less unified focal color – but Avito trades that for a sense of inclusively and breadth.

name: Avito2
reason: Avito’s design incorporates multiple bright colors (blue, green, purple) to reflect its diverse marketplace. These lively accents on a clean white background make the site feel dynamic and user-friendly, while black text provides clear readability.

name: Baidu
reason: Dual red-blue palette mirrors paw-logo; balanced neutrals aid dense Mandarin copy. (SchemeColor)

name: Balenciaga
reason: Balenciaga’s site leans into extreme simplicity – basically black on white, with occasionally a punch of pure red for a graphic, link, or hover effect. This ultra-minimal palette feels deliberately edgy and stripped-down, aligning with the brand’s avant-garde approach. The high contrast makes everything readable and bold. A dash of red (for example, in certain campaign text or error messages) injects a rebellious energy and draws attention to specific elements. Overall, it’s a very gallery-like aesthetic: stark but effective, letting Balenciaga’s unconventional content speak for itself.

name: Bershka
reason: Bershka keeps its interface very minimalistic – largely black text on clean white, with shades of gray for structure. Interestingly, the brand doesn’t rely on a signature UI color (their official brand color is essentially black), likely because their target Gen-Z audience expects a hyper-modern, stripped-down look where the fashion items provide the color. This design approach feels very “cool” and in line with fast trends: it’s almost like a social media feed in its neutrality. The lack of strong accent color means the site can adapt to any season’s styles (neon one month, pastels the next) without clashing. It’s a practical and trendy choice – perhaps not memorable color-wise, but it ensures all focus is on the clothes, and it feels sleek and easy to shop.

name: Bing
reason: A mix of neutral grays with an accent of Bing’s gold creates a clean, professional look, balancing visual interest with simplicity.

name: Block
reason: Electric orange energizes fintech story; high-contrast black/white pairs meet WCAG. (brand Color Code, Block)

name: Bmw
reason: The signature blue and neutral grays create a trustworthy, clean look. White backgrounds with black/gray text feel open and modern, while the blue accent adds a touch of brand character without overwhelming the elegant design.

name: Boohoo
reason: Boohoo’s design often features a bold magenta-pink (#D21F8C) accent against a clean background, giving the site a trendy, of-the-moment feel. This bright accent color is used for CTAs and icons, injecting personality and a sense of urgency (perfect for fast fashion) into the shopping experience. Black text on white keeps the fundamentals easy to read, and light pink touches (#F8BBE8) might be used for hover states or badges, reinforcing the youthful vibe. This scheme feels energetic and fashion-forward – it speaks to the brand’s dynamic style while still maintaining a clear visual hierarchy (since the loudest color is reserved mostly for buttons and highlights).

name: Booking
reason: A strong navy blue defines identity, signifying trust, while bright yellow accents (for deals or availability) draw attention:contentReference[oaicite:68]{index=68}. Black text on white keeps the interface straightforward and easy to use.

name: Bosch
reason: Bosch’s bold red logo color and refined gray palette communicate strength and professionalism. The bright red is used sparingly for emphasis (reflecting precision and engineering), while the variety of grays and white lend a technical, trustworthy tone. It’s a no-nonsense combination that underscores Bosch’s reputation for quality and clarity.

name: Box
reason: Box’s site uses its signature medium blue to establish brand presence and trust. This blue is applied to headers, icons, and call-to-action buttons, conveying security (important for cloud storage). A lighter cyan-blue is sometimes used as a complementary accent, adding depth to the monochromatic scheme. The rest of the design leans on white and a soft gray for backgrounds, keeping the look simple and open. Dark gray text provides the necessary contrast. By focusing on shades of blue with neutral support, Box maintains a cohesive, trustworthy feel that assures users their content is safe and accessible.

name: Broadcom
reason: Saturated red signals speed; pale panels keep enterprise docs readable. (ColorCodesHub)

name: Burberry
reason: Burberry’s site palette draws from its iconic trench coat and tartan: a warm camel beige (#D3BFA6) combined with black, white, and a touch of red (from the stripe in its plaid). This yields a very heritage feel – it’s immediately evocative of the brand. Black or dark brown text on the beige/white backgrounds remains readable, and the red is used sparingly (perhaps in sale notices or small accents) so as not to clash. The combination feels classic and upscale, wrapping the user in the Burberry identity without sacrificing clarity (the warmth of the beige is gentle on the eyes and distinctive).

name: Canon
reason: Canon’s bright red logo color provides a clear focal point amid a very straightforward palette of black, gray, and white. The design feels clean and no-nonsense. Red is used for emphasis (e.g., important buttons or links), ensuring usability stays high while adding a touch of brand personality.

name: Chakra-Ui
mood: Neutral and balanced (soft tones on dark background)
reason: Chakra’s dark mode uses muted teal-blue hues against deep gray surfaces. The softer primary and accent (faded teal and blue) avoid eye fatigue, while off-white text provides sufficient contrast. The result feels gentle and readable, maintaining a consistent, harmonious look that aligns with Chakra’s emphasis on accessibility.

name: Chakra-Ui
mood: Friendly and accessible (clean design with subtle accents)
reason: The palette uses a teal primary (#319795) – Chakra’s default – with a blue accent, conveying a calm and trustworthy feel. Ample white and light gray backgrounds (#F7FAFC) combined with dark gray text ensure high legibility. This accessible color system aligns with Chakra’s goal of usability and inclusivity.

name: Chanel
reason: Chanel epitomizes the black-and-white scheme – the site is predominantly white with black typography, mirroring the brand’s hallmark colors. Any additional hue is minimal; for instance, a hint of gold or ivory might appear in detailing to add a touch of luxury. This high-contrast combo is extremely clear and instantly conveys Chanel’s classic elegance. It’s simple but powerful; the lack of any bright accent is intentional, focusing attention on imagery and reinforcing Chanel’s timeless monochrome identity.

name: Chatgpt
reason: Predominantly black and white with a teal-green accent (the ChatGPT signature color:contentReference[oaicite:55]{index=55}) gives a sleek, techy feel, with high contrast for a futuristic yet clear design.

name: Cisco
reason: Bright aqua accents flows of data; pale cyan blocks unify modular sections. ( EncyColorpedia)

name: Cloudflare
reason: Sunrise orange pair conveys speed & safety; charcoal anchors headlines. (Color Hex, SchemeColor)

name: Cnn
reason: CNN’s signature red:contentReference[oaicite:67]{index=67} accents headlines and links against a clean white and black layout, projecting urgency and authority while ensuring news content remains readable.

name: Co
mood: Same Shopee style – dominated by a single vivid orange tone across the UI, lending a cohesive and energetic feel.
reason: Shopee Indonesia also mirrors the orange-centric design. The consistent use of color builds Shopee’s brand identity in the region but carries the same pros/cons as elsewhere: very engaging but not much color variety for hierarchy beyond that one hue.

name: Coach
reason: Coach’s site palette takes cues from leather and craftsmanship: a rich saddle-brown tone (#8B5F2F) is used alongside neutral whites and blacks. This brown accent (reminiscent of their famous leather bags) adds warmth and a tactile feel to the design without overpowering it. Black text remains the norm for clarity. The combination feels friendly and high-quality – it subtly reminds you of leather goods and heritage, which is perfect for Coach. Contrast is still sufficient (brown is mostly used for decorative touches or headings, not body text), so the overall usability remains strong while the brand story comes through.

name: Codescandy
reason: Strong purple primary signals identity; classic BS alert hues keep UI patterns instantly recognisable. (CodesCandy)

name: Coreui
reason: Bright accents pop over charcoal, maintaining brand identity while WCAG contrast stays above 4.5≤1.

name: Coreui
reason: Cool cyan primary balanced by warm warning/danger; high-chroma signals with soft gray surface keep it accessible and lively.

name: Costco
mood: Traditional and trustworthy. Costco’s design uses a patriotic red, white, and blue motif – red for calls-to-action or headings, blue for accents/backgrounds, on a field of white. The mood is straightforward and warehouse-like (no flashy gradients), conveying reliability and value.
reason: Costco’s color scheme reinforces its brand identity: the red evokes the Costco logo and signage (grabbing attention on things like “SALE” or “Member-only savings”), while the dark blue provides a stable backdrop (often seen in the top navigation or footer). This red/blue combination on white feels very American and conveys solidity – just like walking into a Costco warehouse where signs are simple red on white. It’s a no-nonsense palette that aligns with Costco’s value proposition. The interface remains clean due to ample white and light gray usage; color is applied mainly to guide the eye (red for important info or buttons like “Add to Cart”, blue for links or section headers). This conservative use of color works well for Costco’s demographic, which expects a focus on products/prices over design frills. It’s effective and consistent, though some might find it a tad plain – however, that plainness itself implies that Costco is all about the deals, not about a fancy web aesthetic.

name: Coupa
reason: Coupa's site balances a serious navy blue foundation with pops of a lighter, energetic blue. The dark navy (seen in headers and text) establishes a corporate, trustworthy feel, while the bright cyan-blue is used for buttons and icons to energize the interface and guide the eye. Backgrounds are largely white or very light gray-blue, which keeps the pages looking clean and modern. This two-tone blue approach maintains professionalism for a spend-management platform, yet it's visually engaging, helping important information and calls-to-action stand out.

name: Coupang
mood: Simple and energetic. Coupang's UI uses a multi-tone approach as well: its logo is multi-colored (brown, red, orange, green, blue), but the site largely sticks to neutral backgrounds with sparing use of those colors, yielding a modern yet approachable mood.
reason: Coupang's site feels clean and light. The blue from its palette often serves as the primary action color (blue conveys trust), while warm accents (orange, red) highlight sales or warnings. Most of the interface relies on white backgrounds and gray/black text, which keeps things uncluttered. The rare use of the multiple brand colors means the site doesn't appear rainbow-colored; instead it feels neutral with pops of color where needed (e.g. a red 'Hot' deal tag or green free shipping icon), achieving a balance between brand identity and usability.

name: Craigslist
mood: Extremely minimalistic and utilitarian. Craigslist's design is essentially just browser default colors – a white background and blue/purple links – giving it a no-frills, retro feel. The mood is neutral to a fault, even dull, emphasizing function over form (which, arguably, is part of its charm).
reason: Craigslist's design is the epitome of function over form – by using the default web palette (blue hyperlinks, purple visited links) and almost nothing else, it ensures maximum simplicity and performance. The black text on white background is as high-contrast as it gets, making content legible on any device. This spartan approach has the benefit of never distracting from the content (listings), but it also offers zero visual appeal or brand personality – the site can seem boring or outdated. In Craigslist's case, however, the bare-bones look has become an iconic part of its identity (and even a trust factor, as it feels like a basic community board). It's not a good combination aesthetically by modern standards (no guiding accent color for CTAs, etc.), but it is deliberately simplistic to keep the focus on text.

name: Creative-Tim
reason: The site often showcases bold “material” colors – an orange primary and cyan accent – to grab attention. These bright hues on clean white/gray backgrounds create an exciting mood. Dark charcoal text anchors the design. The combination feels lively and modern, reflecting a design resource site that wants to appear creative and cutting-edge.

name: Cricbuzz
reason: Cricbuzz uses a fresh green:contentReference[oaicite:76]{index=76} reflecting cricket fields, which brings an energetic, sporty feel. The green stands out against white backgrounds, while black text and elements ensure live scores and news are clearly visible.

name: Dailymail
reason: The Daily Mail sticks to a classic news palette with its bold royal blue masthead and white background. The strong blue branding provides instant recognition, while black body text on white keeps the content traditional and easy to read.

name: Daisyui
reason: Vibrant pink-purple pair stands out on near-black; rooted in popular “Dracula” schema.

name: Daisyui
reason: High-saturation primaries give a cheerful, component-library vibe without overpowering.

name: Datadog
reason: Datadog stands out by using purple as its main brand color – a distinctive choice in enterprise tech. The site employs a mid-tone purple for branding and highlights, with an even darker purple for headers or footer areas. This palette gives a sleek, cutting-edge feel, hinting at creativity and insight (suitable for a monitoring platform). Backgrounds are white or a light lavender-gray, ensuring the vivid charts and data visualizations pop. Dark gray text is used for readability. The atypical use of purple differentiates Datadog while still maintaining a clean, technical aesthetic that appeals to its developer audience.

name: Dell1
reason: Dell's use of multiple accents (blue, green, yellow) against a white/gray base creates a lively yet balanced mood. The colored accents are used sparingly for icons or highlights, making the site feel engaging and friendly while the overall structure remains clean and professional.

name: Dell2
reason: Mid-blue masthead anchored by slate copy builds trust; soft gray cards aid scan-ability. ( SchemeColor)

name: Digitalocean
reason: Bright Droplet blue plus breezy tints convey simplicity for coders. (

name: Dior
reason: Dior’s site favors a palette of blacks and soft Dior-grey tones. The use of a medium gray (#999999) for some text and interface elements creates a sophisticated, less harsh contrast than pure black, aligning with Dior’s understated luxury. White backgrounds keep things clean. There’s essentially no bold color – which feels very on-brand (Dior often uses gray as a signature color). This combination feels gentle on the eyes and supremely elegant, letting the craft and color of products themselves provide any needed vibrancy.

name: Discord
mood: Friendly and clean – the light mode feels airy and approachable. Black text on off-white backgrounds is easy to read, and the famous blurple provides pops of personality (e.g. for links or icons). Subtle blue-tinted grays (e.g. #F2F3F5) give the UI a slight cool tone, avoiding pure stark white.
reason: Discord’s design intentionally minimizes distraction in light mode. By using mostly neutral colors (white/gray) and reserving blurple for interactive elements, the platform maintains clarity for text and content. The light theme “plays by the dark mode playbook” by being essentially a dark theme inverted with white paint – meaning it’s simple and functional, even if many users prefer Discord’s dark UI.

name: Discord
mood: Sleek and focused – the dark theme is easy on the eyes for long sessions. Rich “Not Quite Black” charcoal tones (#23272A) form the background, and nearly-white text (#DCDDDE) provides comfortable contrast without harshness. The mood is technical yet playful, thanks to the splash of blurple that gives Discord its identity.
reason: Discord’s dark UI is loved for its low-glare, high-contrast readability. Important status colors (green for online, yellow for idle, red for alerts) are integrated from the official palette, ensuring functional clarity. Overall, the dark theme works with the neon-accented “blurple” and muted grays to create a modern, gaming-friendly atmosphere that aligns with Discord’s community vibe.

name: Disneyplus
reason: Disney+ uses a deep navy blue interface with subtle gradients, creating an immersive backdrop for streaming. Bright blue highlights:contentReference[oaicite:82]{index=82} and white text/icons ensure navigation elements and titles stand out with a polished, cinematic quality.

name: Dmm
mood: Dark-themed and slick. DMM’s site often features a black or dark gray background (especially for media content), giving it a cinematic feel, with white text and occasional red accents. The mood is sophisticated and a bit edgy, fitting both its tech and entertainment content.
reason: DMM’s heavy use of black and dark gray immediately sets it apart from lighter e-commerce sites – it suggests premium digital content and focuses the viewer on video thumbnails or images (which often have bright colors themselves). White text on black provides clear contrast for navigation. The strategic use of red (for example, a red dot on notifications or a red highlight on pricing) adds just enough color to draw attention when needed, without breaking the sleek atmosphere. Red is a good choice here as it stands out strongly against black and aligns with DMM’s branding (red is a common accent in Japanese media sites). This dark UI can be very appealing for nighttime use and for content consumption. It might be less optimal in bright environments due to glare, but overall it gives DMM a distinctive, modern look that resonates with its tech-savvy user base.

name: Docusign
reason: DocuSign’s design prominently features a bold yellow – a color associated with highlights – which is perfect for drawing attention to important actions (like “Sign” buttons). This vibrant yellow, paired with a strong navy blue, creates a trustworthy contrast (blue often implies security). The rest of the interface is clean white and light gray, ensuring the focus stays on document content. Black text on white maximizes legibility. The overall effect is focused and professional, reinforcing trust in a digital contract environment.

name: Dropbox1
reason: Dropbox’s site features a bold royal blue as the core brand color, giving a modern and dependable vibe. This blue is balanced by plenty of white and a soft almost-blueish light gray, which makes pages feel spacious and welcoming. Dark gray text provides a gentle contrast instead of stark black, aligning with Dropbox’s friendly image. A sparing use of a warm orange (for illustrations or minor accents) adds a touch of creativity. The combination is approachable and clean, mirroring Dropbox’s focus on simplicity and user-friendly file sharing.

name: Fendi
reason: Fendi’s site doesn’t shy away from color – it proudly uses the signature Fendi yellow (#FFEF00) for major accents (like headers or sale banners), injecting instant brand recognition. The palette feels youthful and luxurious at once – the yellow adds fun and energy, while black and brown ensure the text and details stay elegant and grounded. It’s a high-impact combination that makes the site feel lively and unmistakably Fendi, without compromising readability (yellow is mostly backdrop with black text on it, which is high contrast).

name: Ferrari

name: Flipkart

reason: Flipkart strikes a pleasing balance: the rich blue conveys trust and tech quality, while the cheery yellow adds a sense of affordability and fun. These brand colors are used judiciously – e.g. blue for the top bar and actionable text, yellow for small promotional badges – ensuring they accent rather than overwhelm the interface. The base is a gentle off-white/gray which is easier on the eyes than pure white, and very dark blue text (#152336) instead of stark black, which together create a slightly softer, refined appearance. This scheme feels welcoming and efficient, aligning with Flipkart’s position as a leading online retailer in India.

name: Ford

name: Gainsight

This restrained palette feels clean and content-first, resonating with developers, while the occasional colored status (green for success, red for errors) aligns with common coding conventions for quick recognition.

It’s a no-frills palette that underscores Givenchy’s modern couture aesthetic; by not introducing any playful colors, it maintains a serious, high-fashion tone that resonates with its brand image.

name: Intuit
reason: Intuit’s color scheme centers on a calm, medium blue which conveys trust and stability – ideal for financial software. White backgrounds and light grays keep interfaces uncluttered. Intuit uses a darker blue for text, ensuring readability and a professional vibe. A fresh green is used sparingly (e.g. for success states or accent graphics), adding a friendly touch. This combination feels clean, credible, and approachable, reinforcing Intuit’s brand values.

name: Jaguar
reason: Jaguar’s dark green (almost black) and metallic grays on white produce a sense of understated luxury. The palette is restrained and sophisticated. name: Jcrew
reason: J.Crew’s site sticks to fundamentals: lots of white space and black text, often accented by a deep, heritage green or similar classic tone. That touch of green (a nod to their traditional collegiate-preppy vibe) adds character without dominating. It’s mostly seen in some headers or links, keeping the interface elegant. The overall look is timeless and easy to read – much like a J.Crew outfit, it’s polished but not loud, allowing the product colors to shine.

name: Jd1
reason: Punchy red mirrors New-Year aesthetic, boosting deals; pale blush panels soften. (brand Color Code)

name: Jd2
mood: Bold and festive. is dominated by a rich Chinese red, reflecting both brand and cultural significance (luck, excitement). The mood is very energetic and urgent – it feels like there are always sales happening (which in JD’s case is true). Paired with white and gray, the red stands out even more.
reason: JD’s heavy use of red is a deliberate choice – in China, red is associated with prosperity and grabs consumer attention like no other color. On red is everywhere: the logo, the top navigation bar, promotional banners, prices, etc. This creates a high-energy environment that can spur impulse buying. White backgrounds and black text are used for product listings, ensuring that despite the abundance of red, the core information remains legible. Light gray (#F5F5F5) is often used to separate sections or as background for less critical content, which gives the eyes a break from all the red. The scheme is very powerful for driving engagement (a user can hardly miss a “Double 11” sale banner in bright red), though by Western aesthetics it might seem too intense. However, it fits the local context and JD’s brand – it conveys that is a place of constant deals and excitement. The contrast is excellent (red/white/black), so usability isn’t compromised; if anything, the challenge is making sure the overuse of red doesn’t reduce its impact, but JD handles this by using different shades and lots of visual content. In summary, it’s a bold but effective combination that has helped JD become instantly recognizable.

name: Jeep
reason: Jeep’s olive green and utilitarian grays instantly convey an outdoorsy, adventurous spirit. The green serves as a nod to the brand’s off-road heritage, while black on white text keeps information clear. The subdued, earthy palette feels sturdy and authentic, resonating with Jeep’s rugged image.

name: Kia
reason: Kia’s bright red combined with deep nearly-black and gray gives an energetic, modern vibe. The strong red catches attention for key calls-to-action, while the dark text and light backgrounds ensure information is crisp. The mix feels dynamic but still balanced for readability.

name: Kleinanzeigen
mood: Casual and approachable. Kleinanzeigen (formerly eBay Kleinanzeigen) uses a light green and yellow palette, giving it a friendly, neighborly feel. The colors are soft and optimistic, creating a sense of community and ease – appropriate for a local classifieds platform.
reason: The light green gives Kleinanzeigen a fresh, eco-friendly tone (suitable for second-hand trading), and it feels welcoming rather than corporate. Important details or calls-to-action may use the complementary yellow (for example, highlight banners or icons), which adds a cheerful pop of color and improves visual hierarchy. The combination of green and yellow is reminiscent of spring – aligning with the idea of renewal and new listings. Against a crisp white background with black text, these colors stand out clearly. This scheme works well to foster a community vibe and differentiate Kleinanzeigen from more commercial e-commerce sites. One could say the colors are a bit light (pastel) which might reduce contrast for some UI elements, but overall the design prioritizes clarity and friendliness, which is fitting for its purpose.

name: Lamborghini
reason: Lamborghini’s gold-on-black palette feels ultra-premium and dramatic. The dark theme lets the golden-yellow accents (logo and highlights) glow with high impact. White or light text on black ensures readability. This combination conveys exclusivity and power, perfectly in line with the luxury sports car image.

name: Leboncoin
mood: Friendly and inviting. Leboncoin’s interface revolves around a bright orange (like a sunset hue) which gives it a warm, community vibe. With white and light greys making up the background, the orange elements create a sense of excitement and catch the eye without overwhelming.
reason: Leboncoin’s orange immediately conveys a sense of approachability and energy, fitting for a classifieds site where activity and new posts are constant. Orange highlights new listings or important calls-to-action, making the user instinctively notice them. The overall design uses a lot of white space and very light gray, which not only modernizes the look (especially compared to older Craigslist-style classifieds) but also gives breathing room to the bright orange so it doesn’t feel too heavy. Black text ensures readability. The result is a pleasant, upbeat design that feels trustworthy (thanks to its simplicity) yet lively (thanks to the splashes of orange). It effectively combines community warmth with a clean interface.

name: Lego
reason: The LEGO site wisely incorporates the brand’s hallmark primary colors – a sunny yellow (like the Lego figure heads) for action buttons and a vivid red for highlights – to create a fun, kid-friendly mood. These bright hues pop against the white page, drawing users to important CTAs or promotions. Coupled with simple black text, the scheme is lively yet legible, reinforcing LEGO’s playful brand identity.

name: Lenovo1

name: Levi
reason: Levi’s leverages its iconic red tab color (#CE1126) for immediate brand recognition – you’ll see that red in logos and important buttons. The rest of the UI is anchored by white and black with hints of denim blue. This gives the site a patriotic, all-American feel (red, white, and blue) which is very consistent with Levi’s branding. The combination is not only evocative of jeans and the US flag, it’s also functional: red and blue accents draw attention to key calls-to-action or links, while the majority of text remains black on white for simplicity. It feels friendly, down-to-earth, and nostalgic in the right way, while still being easy to navigate.

name: Lg

name: LinkedIn
mood: Professional and clean – the light theme feels open, with plenty of white space conveying a modern, “business casual” tone. reason: LinkedIn’s palette is optimized for readability and professionalism. White backgrounds and dark text ensure maximum contrast for reading job posts or profiles. The brand’s blue is used sparingly (on links, buttons, and highlights) so that it stands out as a call-to-action without overwhelming the interface. The result is a conservative yet approachable design befitting a professional network.

name: LinkedIn
mood: Elegant and low-key – the dark mode uses black and deep charcoal (#313335) as a backdrop, lending a sleek, modern feel to the professional content. White and light gray text (e.g. #CACCCE) on black maintains legibility while being easier on the eyes in low light. The familiar blue accents are slightly softened but still present, preserving LinkedIn’s brand feel.
reason: Dark mode on LinkedIn is designed to reduce eye strain during nighttime browsing while maintaining contrast ratios for readability. The palette still reflects LinkedIn’s brand (blue and white) but flips the brightness: backgrounds become nearly black, and text becomes light. This mode works well for users who prefer a darker UI without sacrificing the clarity and professional tone expected of LinkedIn.

name: Linktr
reason: Linktree’s branding features a bright neon-green, which is very eye-catching on its minimalist site. The rest of the palette is stark: lots of white for background and solid black for text, ensuring that the fluorescent green stands out even more. Gray is used sparingly for secondary text or icons. This high-contrast scheme is simple but memorable, making Linktree links instantly recognizable and easy to interact with.

name: Linode

It’s a rich combination that feels opulent but still subtle enough to let product visuals stand out.

name: Lucid

name: Mail

name: Mailchimp

The heavy use of yellow could be overwhelming, but Mailchimp tempers it with white sections and muted gray-beige tones. The result feels fun and approachable yet still clean. This unconventional palette differentiates Mailchimp and reinforces its playful brand personality while maintaining readability.

name: Mango
reason: Mango’s site sticks to black text on white with very subtle warm tones (like an off-white backdrop). This minimalist palette appears refined and modern, aligning with the brand’s contemporary style. The lack of any strong accent color actually works here – it creates a calm, magazine-like layout where the clothing images add the only pops of color. The result is quietly sophisticated and easy to read.

name: Mantine
reason: Dark neutrals spotlight the blue brand color while large spacing of Mantine UI keeps interfaces airy.

name: Mantine
reason: Gentle blue gradients create approachable yet professional feel; subtle contrast ideal for SaaS UIs.

name: Marca
reason: Marca’s strong red branding (matching its logo and sports emphasis) dominates the design, conveying passion and energy. Paired with white backgrounds and black text, it ensures that headlines and scores are bold and easily noticed.

name: Marksandspencer
reason: M&S incorporates its heritage dark green (#255C3B) for a touch of tradition (often seen in its logo and some accents), on top of a largely white/black canvas. This green conveys quality and heritage, and it’s used in a restrained way so the site still feels clean and modern. Black text on white provides strong contrast for readability. The overall palette feels polished and trustworthy – much like the brand itself – giving a sense of reliability while still being easy to navigate.

name: Max
reason: Launched with a signature bold blue interface for an engaging look, Max has since moved toward a sleek black-and-white scheme:contentReference[oaicite:95]{index=95} reminiscent of HBO’s classic branding. This evolution balances eye-catching color with premium simplicity to highlight content.

name: Mazda
reason: Mazda’s bright blue coupled with soft silver-gray gives a friendly, approachable tone. The vivid blue adds personality and hints at excitement (reflecting their sporty image), while the neutral grays and black text on white keep things simple and readable. The effect is inviting and modern without fussiness.

name: Mercadolibre
mood: Bright and upbeat. Mercado Livre (Mercado Libre) uses a vibrant yellow as its defining color – cheerful and attention-grabbing – paired with navy blue or black for contrast. The mood is optimistic and energetic, consistent with a bustling marketplace.
reason: The bright yellow instantly identifies Mercado Livre, creating a sense of positivity and urgency (yellow signals deals or important info). This high-impact color is used in moderation – often in the header or promo banners – so as not to strain the eyes. Deep blue provides an excellent counterpoint, used for text or buttons, adding a sense of trust and readability against yellow or white. The combination is very effective: it draws users in (yellow for excitement) but still feels grounded (blue for stability), perfect for a large e-commerce platform.

name: Mercari
mood: Clean with bold accents. Mercari’s design uses a lot of white and light gray, with punches of red (and some blue) reflecting its logo icon. The mood is modern and friendly – mostly neutral but with occasional bright spots that add personality and indicate action.
reason: Mercari employs red as its attention-grabber – e.g. the sell button or alerts might be in this bold red, which energizes the otherwise minimal interface. Red naturally draws the eye, so Mercari smartly uses it for key CTAs. A complementary bright blue appears in some icons or links, adding a second layer of emphasis (and matching the blue dot in Mercari’s logo). This red/blue on white scheme gives Mercari a friendly, techy feel (similar to certain social apps). It’s effective because the colors are used sparingly; most of the UI is grayscale, so when a red price or blue link appears, it clearly signals something clickable or important. The balance keeps the site feeling open and uncluttered, though compared to competitors with richer palettes, Mercari might appear a tad plain at first glance – a conscious choice to highlight content over chrome.

name: Mercedes-Benz
reason: A range of deep blue-grays and crisp white conveys an upscale, professional tone. The neutral palette feels elegant and refined, with excellent contrast that underscores the brand’s luxury image.

name: Meta
reason: Bright “Meta-blue” owns identity across light surfaces; subtle greys reduce fatigue. (

name: Metronic
reason: Nearly-black backgrounds relieve eye-strain while neon blue/cyan signals retain brand identity. (Keenthemes Inc.)

name: Metronic
reason: Bright azure primary with aqua accent and bold warning/danger hues give a vivid yet professional dashboard palette. (

name: Michaelkors
reason: Michael Kors employs a classic black-and-white foundation accented by warm gold tones (#CFAE70). This gold (often seen in MK’s logo and product hardware) adds a sense of attainable luxury to the interface – you might see it in icons or callout headings. The palette feels luxurious but not aloof; black text on white ensures readability, and the gold provides just enough shine to remind users of the brand’s glamour. It’s a combination that’s both fashion-forward and user-friendly, conveying a sense of accessible luxury.

name: Microsoft
reason: Charcoal base with blue accents provides legible contrast across apps in low light.

name: Microsoft1
reason: Four-tile spectrum signals breadth while retaining harmony by equal saturation. (Color Hex)

name: Microsoft2
reason: Microsoft’s web presence uses a clean white canvas with straightforward black text, accented by the friendly blue often seen in Windows products. The soft neutral grays support the layout without drawing attention, letting the blue highlights (e.g. for links or buttons) guide the user’s eye. This familiar combination feels comfortable and intuitive, reinforcing Microsoft’s user-friendly brand persona.

name: Microsoft3
reason: Mid-blue evokes cloud depth; airy tints ease dense pricing tables. (SchemeColor)

name: Microsoft4
reason: Microsoft uses its signature blue as a primary color, conveying trust and innovation. Neutral grays and ample white space create a clean, business-like feel. This balanced palette ensures high contrast and readability, reinforcing a professional yet approachable design.

name: Microsoft5
reason: Microsoft’s palette uses its four iconic tile colors (blue, green, yellow, red) in a restrained way on a white canvas with black text. This yields a friendly yet professional look. The pops of color are used for icons or highlights, making the interface feel lively and balanced while maintaining clarity for productivity.

name: Microsoftonline
reason: Uses Microsoft’s palette (blue, green, yellow, red:contentReference[oaicite:65]{index=65}) in subtle ways against a predominantly white, minimal interface, creating a professional and balanced look.

name: Miro
reason: Miro’s site uses a bright, almost golden yellow as its signature color, instantly giving off a creative and energetic vibe (suitable for a collaborative whiteboard tool). This lively yellow is offset by a deep indigo/purple (often used in backgrounds or text), which adds seriousness and contrast. The combination is striking and modern. Generous white and a soft cream background are used to avoid eye fatigue and to make colorful sticky-note graphics pop. The result is a playful yet purposeful palette that encourages creativity while keeping interface elements clear.

name: Monday
reason: interface is known for its vibrant color-coding, and its marketing site reflects this with a rainbow of accent colors. A deep indigo acts as a primary anchor (used in logos and some text), while the supporting palette includes bright yellow, green, and pink – echoing the product’s status labels and branding. These colors pop against a clean white background, immediately conveying a sense of energy and organization. Dark neutral text ties it all together. The bold multicolor approach not only catches attention but also reinforces Monday’s identity as a dynamic, user-friendly work OS where color is used functionally and playfully.

name: Mudblazor
mood: Bold and vibrant (neon accents on dark background)
reason: The dark theme uses deep grey surfaces with a glowing purple primary and pink secondary. Light text on nearly-black backgrounds ensures readability. The vibrant colors “pop” against the dark, giving a sleek, high-contrast appearance that feels both energetic and polished.

name: Mudblazor
reason: A purple primary paired with a hot-pink accent gives a bold, modern vibe. Generous white and light grey surfaces keep the design open, while dark text ensures legibility. The contrast between vibrant highlights and neutral backgrounds creates an engaging yet professional UI.

name: Mui
reason: Uses a near-black background (#121212) with softer tints of the brand colors (sky-blue and pink) to reduce eye strain. Gray-white text maintains readability. The overall effect is modern and easy on the eyes, preserving Material Design’s clarity in low-light conditions.

name: Mui
reason: Stays true to Material Design with a vibrant blue primary and purple secondary, complemented by neutral whites and charcoals. This combination is well-balanced and tested for accessibility, providing clear visual hierarchy and consistency across UI elements.
